original: sa taṃ dṛṣṭvā cintayati na śakyata eṣā nadī janasahasreṇāpi tenaiva yathā vāhayituṃ kimaṅga punarmayaikena śakyo bāhayituṃ sa pratinivṛttaḥ
analyzed: sa tam dṛṣṭvā cintayati na śakyate eṣā nadī jana sahasreṇa api tena eva yathā vāhayitum kim aṅga punar mayā ekena śakyaḥ bāhayitum sa pratinivṛttaḥ
translated: Seeing this, he thought, It is not possible for even a thousand people to carry this river by themselves, let alone me alone. I am unable to carry it. He turned back.

original: atha khalu kuladevate jalavāhanaḥ śreṣṭhiputraḥ śīghraṃ śīghramupasaṃkrānto yena rājā Bagchi
analyzed: atha khalu kula devate jalavāhanaḥ śreṣṭhi putraḥ śīghram śīghram upasaṃkrāntaḥ yena rājā bagchi
translated: Then, O Kuladevata, the merchant's son Jalavahana quickly went to King Bagshi

analyzed: sureśva prabhaḥ tena upajagāma
translated: Sureshaprabha and approached him.

original: upagamya rājñaḥ sureśvaraprabhasya pādau śirasā natvaikānte niṣaṇṇaḥ /
analyzed: upagamya rājñaḥ sureśvara prabhasya pādau śirasā natvā ekānte niṣaṇṇaḥ
translated: Having approached, he bowed his head at the feet of King Sureshaprabha and sat to one side.

analyzed: imām prakṛtim ārocayāti sma
translated: He reported this situation:

original: mayā khalu devasya viṣaye sarvagrāmanagaranigamajanapadarāṣṭrarājadhānīṣu sattvānāṃ vyādhayaḥ praśamitāḥ /
analyzed: mayā khalu devasya viṣaye sarva grāma nagara nigama janapada rāṣṭra rājadhānīṣu sattvānām vyādhayaḥ praśamitāḥ
translated: Your Majesty, in your kingdom, in all the villages, towns, markets, countries, kingdoms, and capitals, I have cured the illnesses of beings.

analyzed: tatra amuṣmin sthāne ṭavīsaṃbhavā nāma puṣkariṇī
translated: There, in that place, there is a pond called Atava-sambhava.

analyzed: tatra daśa matsya sahasrāṇi prativasanti jala prahīṇāni āditya paritāpitāni
translated: In it, ten thousand fish are living, deprived of water and tormented by the sun.

original: taddadātu me devo viṃśatigajā yathā teṣāṃ tiryagyonigatānāṃ jīvitaṃ dadāmīti /
analyzed: tat dadātu me devaḥ viṃśati gajāḥ yathā teṣām tiryagyoni gatānām jīvitam dadāmi iti
translated: May Your Majesty give me twenty elephants, so that I can give life to those animals in the animal realm.

original: yathā manuṣyāṇāṃ dattamājñaptaṃ khalu rājñā sureśvaraprabheṇāmātyānāṃ dadata mahāvaidyarājasya viṃśatigajān /
analyzed: yathā manuṣyāṇām dattam ājñaptam khalu rājñā sureśvaraprabheṇa amātyānām dadata mahā vaidya rājasya viṃśati gajān
translated: As the king Sureśvara-prabha commanded the ministers, Give twenty elephants to the great physician king.

analyzed: amātyāḥ āhuḥ
translated: The ministers said, We have given them.

original: upasaṃkrama mahāsattva yena hastiśālā upagṛhṇīṣva viṃśatigajān kuru sattvānāṃ sukham //
analyzed: upasaṃkrama mahāsattva yena hasti śālāḥ upagṛhṇīṣva viṃśati gajān kuru sattvānām sukham
translated: Come, great being, to the elephant stable and take twenty elephants and bring happiness to the beings.

original: atha khalu kuladevate jalavāhanaḥ sārdhaṃ jalāmbareṇa ca svaputreṇa viṃśatigajān gṛhītvā nāgaśauṇḍikānāṃ sakāśācchataśo dṛśīnāṃ pratigṛhya
analyzed: atha khalu kula devate jalavāhanaḥ sārdham jalāmbareṇa ca sva putreṇa viṃśati gajān gṛhītvā nāga śauṇḍikānām sakāśāt śataśas dṛśīnām pratigṛhya
translated: Then, Noble Goddess, Jala-vahana, together with his son Jala-ambara, took twenty elephants from the elephant trainers and accepted hundreds of gold coins from them.

original: yatra jalāgamā nāma mahānadī pravahati /🔽tatropasaṃkramyodakena tā dṛtīḥ pūrayitvā gajapṛṣṭha udakamāropya śīghraṃ śīghraṃ yenāṭavīsaṃbhavā puṣkariṇī tenopasaṃkrāntaḥ /
analyzed: yatra jalāgamā nāma mahā nadī pravahati  tatra upasaṃkramya udakena tāḥ dṛtīḥ pūrayitvā gaja pṛṣṭhe udakam āropya śīghram śīghram yena aṭavī saṃbhavā puṣkariṇī tena upasaṃkrāntaḥ
translated: He went to the place where the great river named Jala-agama flows.🔽There he filled the leather bags with water, loaded them on the elephants, and quickly went to the pond in the forest.

original: upasaṃkramya tadudakaṃ hastipṛṣṭhādavatārya tāṃ puṣkariṇīṃ caturdiśamudakena pūrayitvā caturdiśaṃ ca kramati /
analyzed: upasaṃkramya tat udakam hasti pṛṣṭhāt avatārya tām puṣkariṇīm caturdiśam udakena pūrayitvā caturdiśam ca kramati
translated: Having arrived there, he took the water down from the elephants' backs and filled the pond with water from all sides. Then he walked around in all directions.

original: yena yena jalavāhano 'nucaṅkramati tena tena daśamatsyasahasrāṇyanudhāvanti //
analyzed: yena yena jala vāhanaḥ nucaṅkramati tena tena daśa matsya sahasrāṇi anudhāvanti
translated: Wherever Jalavahana went, ten thousand fish followed him.

analyzed: atha khalu kula devate jala vāhanasya etat abhavat
translated: Then, Kuladevi, this thought occurred to Jalavahana:

analyzed: kimartham etāni daśa matsya sahasrāṇi yena aham tena pradhāvanti
translated: Why do these ten thousand fish run after me wherever I go?

analyzed: tasya punar etat abhavat
translated: He thought again:

original: nūnamete matsyāḥ kṣudhāgninā paripīḍitā mama sakāśādbhojanaṃ parimārgayanti /
analyzed: nūnam ete matsyāḥ kṣudhā agninā paripīḍitāḥ mama sakāśāt bhojanam parimārgayanti
translated: Surely these fish, tormented by the fire of hunger, are seeking food from me.

analyzed: yat nūnam aham bhojanam prayaccheyam
translated: I should give them food.

original: atha khalu kuladevate jalavāhanaḥ svaputraṃ jalāmbarametadavocat /
analyzed: atha khalu kula devate jalavāhanaḥ sva putram jalāmbaram etat avocat
translated: Then, Kuladevi, Jalavahana said to his son Jalamvama:

original: gaccha kulaputra svakaṃ niveśanaṃ sarvabalataraṃ hastinamabhirūhya ca śīdhraṃ śīghramupasaṃkramya🔽pitāmahasya śreṣṭhina evaṃ vadeha bho tāta jalavāhana evaṃ vadati yatkiṃcidatra gṛhe
analyzed: gaccha kula putra svakam niveśanam sarva balataram hastinam abhirūhya ca śīdhram śīghram upasaṃkramya  pitāmahasya śreṣṭhinaḥ evam vada iha bho tāta jalavāhanaḥ evam vadati yat kiṃcid atra gṛhe
translated: Go, son, to your own house, mount the strongest elephant, and quickly come back🔽and tell your grandfather, the merchant, 'Sir, Jalavahana says that whatever prepared food there is in the house,

analyzed: bhisaṃskṛtam bhojanam syāt mātā pitroḥ bhrātṛ bhaginyoḥ dāsī dāsa karmakarasya
translated: whether for mother, father, brother, sister, male or female slaves, or workers,

original: kṛtaśaḥ sarvamekatra piṇḍīkṛtvā jalāmbarasya hastipṛṣṭamavaropya jalavāhanāya śīghraṃ śīghraṃ visarjaya //
analyzed: kṛtaśas sarvam ekatra piṇḍīkṛtvā jala ambarasya hasti pṛṣṭam avaropya jala vāhanāya śīghram śīghram visarjaya
translated: Having made everything into a single lump, place it on the back of an elephant, and quickly send it off to be carried by water.

original: atha khalu jalāmbaro dārako hastinamabhiruhya śīghraṃ śīghraṃ dhāvati sma /
analyzed: atha khalu jalāmbaraḥ dārakaḥ hastinam abhiruhya śīghram śīghram dhāvati sma
translated: Then the boy Jalaambara, having mounted the elephant, ran quickly.

original: yena svakaṃ niveśanaṃ tenopasaṃkrāmadupasaṃmyaitāṃ prakṛtaṃ pitāmahasyāgra ārocayāmāsa vistareṇa yathā pūrvoktam /
analyzed: yena svakam niveśanam tena upasaṃkrāmat upasaṃmya etām prakṛtam pitāmahasya agre ārocayāmāsa vistareṇa yathā pūrva uktam
translated: He went to his own house and reported this matter to his grandfather in detail, just as it was said before.

original: tatsarvaṃ pitāmahena jalāmbarāya visarjitam //🔽atha khalu jalambaro dārakastadbhojanaṃ hastipṛṣṭhamupanāmya hastinamabhiruhya yenāṭavīsaṃbhavā puṣkariṇī tenopasaṃkrāmat //
analyzed: tat sarvam pitāmahena jala ambarāya visarjitam  atha khalu jalambaraḥ dārakaḥ tat bhojanam hasti pṛṣṭham upanāmya hastinam abhiruhya yena aṭavī saṃbhavā puṣkariṇī tena upasaṃkrāmat
translated: All that was sent by the grandfather to Jalaambara.🔽Then the boy Jalaambara, having placed that food on the back of the elephant, mounted the elephant and went to the pond in the forest.

original: atha khalu jalavāhanaḥ svakaṃ putraṃ jalāmbaramāgataṃ dṛṣṭvā hṛṣṭastuṣṭa udagraḥ putrasyāntikādbhojanaṃ pratigṛhya cchittvā tatra puṣkariṇyāṃ
analyzed: atha khalu jalavāhanaḥ svakam putram jala ambaram āgatam dṛṣṭvā hṛṣṭaḥ tuṣṭaḥ udagraḥ putrasya antikāt bhojanam pratigṛhya chittvā tatra puṣkariṇyām
translated: Then Jalaavaha, seeing his own son Jalaambara come, was delighted, pleased, and overjoyed. Having received the food from his son, he cut it up and threw it into that pond.

analyzed: prakṣipati sma
translated: He threw it into the pond.

analyzed: tena āhāreṇa tāni daśa matsya sahasrāṇi saṃtarpitāni
translated: By that food, those ten thousand fish were satisfied.

analyzed: punar tasya etat abhavat
translated: Again, this occurred to him:

original: śrutaṃ me pareṇa kālasamayenāraṇyāyatane bhikṣurmahāyānadhārayamāna ityāha /
analyzed: śrutam me pareṇa kāla samayena araṇya āyatane bhikṣuḥ mahāyāna dhārayamānaḥ iti āha
translated: I heard from someone in the past, In a forest dwelling, a monk who upholds the Mahayana said.

original: yo ratnaśikhinastathāgatasyārhataḥ samyaksaṃbuddhasya maraṇakālasamaye nāmadheyaṃ śṛṇuyāt /
analyzed: yaḥ ratnaśikhinaḥ tathāgatasya arhataḥ samyaksaṃbuddhasya maraṇa kāla samaye nāmadheyam śṛṇuyāt
translated: Whoever hears the name of the Tathagata, the Arhat, the Perfectly Enlightened Ratna-SikhI at the time of death,

analyzed: sa svarga loke upapatsyati iti
translated: will be reborn in the heavenly world.

original: yannūnamahameṣāṃ matsyānāṃ gambhīraṃ pratītyasamutpādaṃ dharmaṃ deśayeyam /
analyzed: yat nūnam aham eṣām matsyānām gambhīram pratītyasamutpādam dharmam deśayeyam
translated: I should now teach these fish the profound dependent origination,

analyzed: ratnaśikhinaḥ tathāgatasya arhataḥ samyaksaṃbuddhasya nāmadheyam śrāvayeyam
translated: and make them hear the name of the Tathagata, the Arhat, the Perfectly Enlightened Ratna-SikhI.

original: tena ca samayena tasmiñjambudvīpe dvighādṛṣṭiḥ sattvānāmabhūt /
analyzed: tena ca samayena tasmin jambudvīpe dvighā adṛṣṭiḥ sattvānām abhūt
translated: At that time, in that Jambudvipa, the views of sentient beings were divided into two.

analyzed: kecid mahāyānam abhiśraddhayanti kecid kleśayanti
translated: Some had faith in the Mahayana, while others were hostile to it.

original: atha khalu punarjalavāhanaḥ śreṣṭhiputrastasyāṃ velāyāmubhau pādau jānumātraṃ tatra puṣkariṇyāṃ praveśyaivaṃ cidānamudānayāmāsa /
analyzed: atha khalu punar jalavāhanaḥ śreṣṭhi putraḥ tasyām velāyām ubhau pādau jānu mātram tatra puṣkariṇyām praveśya evam cidānam udānayāmāsa
translated: Then, at that time, Jalavahana, the son of the merchant, entered the lotus pond up to his knees and uttered this aspiration:

original: namastasya bhagavato ratnaśikhinastathāgatasyārhataḥ samyaksaṃbuddhasya purvabodhisattvacaryāṃ caramāṇasya evaṃ praṇidhānamabhūt /
analyzed: namaḥ tasya bhagavataḥ ratnaśikhinaḥ tathāgatasya arhataḥ samyaksaṃbuddhasya purva bodhisattva caryām caramāṇasya evam praṇidhānam abhūt
translated: Homage to that Blessed One, the Tathāgata, the Arhat, the Perfectly Enlightened Ratnaśikhin, when he was practicing the conduct of a bodhisattva in the past, made this aspiration:

original: ye keciddaśasu dikṣu maraṇakālasamaye mama nāmadheyaṃ śṛṇuyuste tataścyutvā devānāṃ trāyastriṃśānāṃ sabhāgatāyāmupapadyeyuḥ //
analyzed: ye kecid daśasu dikṣu maraṇa kāla samaye mama nāmadheyam śṛṇuyuḥ te tatas cyutvā devānām trāyastriṃśānām sabhā gatāyām upapadyeyuḥ
translated: May those in the ten directions who hear my name at the time of death, after passing away from there, be reborn in the company of the gods of the Heaven of the Thirty-Three.

analyzed: bagchi
translated: Bagchi

original: atha khalu jalavāhanaḥ śreṣṭhidārakasteṣāṃ tiryagyonigatānāmimaṃ dharmaṃ deśayati sma /
analyzed: atha khalu jalavāhanaḥ śreṣṭhi dārakaḥ teṣām tiryagyoni gatānām imam dharmam deśayati sma
translated: Then, the merchant's son Jala, taught this Dharma to those who had been reborn as animals:

analyzed: yat uta asmāt idam bhavati asya utpādāt idam utpadyate  yat uta avidyā pratyayāḥ saṃskārāḥ
translated: This arises from that, and from the arising of this, that arises.🔽Namely, conditioned by ignorance are volitional formations.

analyzed: saṃskāra pratyayam vijñānam
translated: Conditioned by volitional formations is consciousness.

analyzed: vijñāna pratyayam nāma rūpam
translated: Conditioned by consciousness is name-and-form.

analyzed: nāma rūpa pratyayam ṣaṣ āyatanam
translated: Conditioned by name-and-form are the six sense bases.

analyzed: ṣaṣ āyatana pratyayaḥ sparśaḥ  sparśa pratyayā vedanā
translated: Conditioned by the six sense bases is contact.🔽Conditioned by contact is feeling.

analyzed: vedanā pratyayā tṛṣṇā
translated: Conditioned by feeling is craving.

analyzed: tṛṣṇā pratyayam upādānam  upādāna pratyayaḥ bhavaḥ
translated: Conditioned by craving is clinging.🔽Conditioned by clinging is becoming.

analyzed: bhava pratyayā jātiḥ
translated: Conditioned by becoming is birth.

original: jātipratyayā jarāmaraṇaśokaparidevaduḥkhadaurmanasyopāyāsā bhavatyevamasya kevalasya mahato duḥkhaskandhasya samudayo bhavati yadutāvidyānirodhātsaṃrakāranirodhaḥ
analyzed: jāti pratyayā jarā maraṇa śoka parideva duḥkha daurmanasya upāyāsā bhavati evam asya kevalasya mahataḥ duḥkha skandhasya samudayaḥ bhavati yat uta avidyā nirodhāt saṃrakāra nirodhaḥ
translated: From the cessation of birth comes the cessation of old age, death, grief, lamentation, pain, sorrow, and despair. Thus the cessation of this entire great mass of suffering occurs. That is to say, from the cessation of ignorance comes the cessation of formations.

analyzed: saṃskāra nirodhāt vijñāna nirodhaḥ
translated: From the cessation of formations comes the cessation of consciousness.

analyzed: vijñāna nirodhāt nāma rūpa nirodhaḥ  nāma rūpa nirodhāt ṣaṣ āyatana nirodhaḥ
translated: From the cessation of consciousness comes the cessation of name-and-form.🔽From the cessation of name-and-form comes the cessation of the six sense bases.

analyzed: ṣaṣ āyatana nirodhāt sparśa nirodhaḥ  sparśa nirodhāt vedanā nirodhaḥ
translated: From the cessation of the six sense bases comes the cessation of contact.🔽From the cessation of contact comes the cessation of feeling.

analyzed: vedanā nirodhāt tṛṣṇā nirodhaḥ  tṛṣṇā nirodhāt upādāna nirodhaḥ
translated: From the cessation of feeling comes the cessation of craving.🔽From the cessation of craving comes the cessation of clinging.

analyzed: upādāna nirodhāt bhava nirodhaḥ
translated: From the cessation of clinging comes the cessation of becoming.

analyzed: bhava nirodhāt jāti nirodhaḥ
translated: From the cessation of becoming comes the cessation of birth.

analyzed: jāti nirodhāt jarā maraṇa śoka parideva duḥkha daurmanasya upāyāsāḥ nirudhyate
translated: From the cessation of birth comes the cessation of old age, death, grief, lamentation, pain, sorrow, and despair.

analyzed: kevalam asya mahataḥ duḥkha skandhasya nirodhaḥ bhavati
translated: Thus the cessation of this entire great mass of suffering occurs.

original: iti hi kuladevate tena kālena tena samayena jalavāhanaḥ śreṣṭhiputrasteṣāṃ tiryagyonigatānāmimāṃ dhārmikakathāṃ kathayati sma /
analyzed: iti hi kuladevate tena kālena tena samayena jalavāhanaḥ śreṣṭhi putraḥ teṣām tiryagyoni gatānām imām dhārmika kathām kathayati sma
translated: Thus, O Goddess, at that time, on that occasion, Jālavāhana, the merchant's son, spoke this Dharma discourse to those beings in the animal realm.

original: sārdhaṃ putrābhyāṃ jalāmbareṇa jalagarbheṇa ca punarapi svagṛhamanuprāptaḥ //
analyzed: sārdham putrābhyām jalāmbareṇa jalagarbheṇa ca punar api sva gṛham anuprāptaḥ
translated: Together with his two sons, Jalambara and Jalagarbha, he returned to his own house.

original: athāpareṇa kālena samayena jalavāhanaḥ śreṣṭhiputro mahotsavaṃ paribhujya mahotsavamatto śayane śayitaḥ /
analyzed: atha apareṇa kālena samayena jalavāhanaḥ śreṣṭhi putraḥ mahā utsavam paribhujya mahā utsava mattaḥ śayane śayitaḥ
translated: Then, at another time, on another occasion, Jālavāhana, the merchant's son, having enjoyed a great festival, intoxicated with the great festival, lay down on his bed.

original: tena ca kālena tena samayena mahānimittaḥ prādurbhūtaḥ /
analyzed: tena ca kālena tena samayena mahā nimittaḥ prādurbhūtaḥ
translated: At that time, on that occasion, a great sign appeared.

original: yattasyā rātryāmatyayena tāni daśamatsyasahasrāṇi kālagatāni deveṣu trāyastriṃśatsu sabhāgatāyāmupapannāni /
analyzed: yat tasyāḥ rātryām atyayena tāni daśa matsya sahasrāṇi kālagatāni deveṣu trāyastriṃśatsu sabhāgatāyām upapannāni
translated: That, at the end of that night, those ten thousand fish died and were reborn among the gods in the Heaven of the Thirty-Three.

analyzed: saha upapannānām ca eṣām evaṃrūpaḥ cetasaḥ parivitarkaḥ utpannaḥ
translated: As soon as they were reborn, this kind of thought arose in their minds:

analyzed: kena vayam kuśala karma hetunā iha deveṣu trāyastriṃśeṣu upapannāḥ
translated: By what cause of wholesome action were we reborn here among the gods in the Heaven of the Thirty-Three?

analyzed: teṣām etat abhūt
translated: They thought this:

analyzed: vayam asmin jambudvīpe daśa matsya sahasrāṇi abhūvan
translated: We were ten thousand fish in this Jambudvīpa.

original: te vayaṃ tiryagyonigatā jalavāhanena śreṣṭhidārakeṇa prabhūtenodakena saṃtarpitā bhojanavareṇa ca /
analyzed: te vayam tiryagyoni gatāḥ jala vāhanena śreṣṭhi dārakeṇa prabhūtena udakena saṃtarpitāḥ bhojana vareṇa ca
translated: We, being in the animal realm, were satisfied with abundant water and excellent food by the merchant's son Jālavāhana.

analyzed: gambhīraḥ ca asmākam pratītyasamutpāda dharmaḥ deśitaḥ
translated: And the profound teaching of dependent origination was given to us.

analyzed: ratnaśikhinaḥ tathāgatasya arhataḥ samyaksaṃbuddhasya nāmadheyam śrāvitāḥ
translated: They heard the name of the Tathāgata, the Arhat, the Perfectly Enlightened One Ratnaśikhin.

original: Bagchi tena kuśaladharmahetunā tena pratyayeneha vayaṃ deveṣūpapannāḥ /
analyzed: tena kuśala dharma hetunā tena pratyayena iha vayam deveṣu upapannāḥ
translated: By that root of merit, by that cause, we were reborn here among the gods.

analyzed: yat nūnam vayam yena jalavāhanaḥ śreṣṭhi dārakaḥ tena upasaṃkramemaḥ
translated: Let us now go to the merchant's son Jalavāhana.

analyzed: upasaṃkramya tasya pūjām kariṣyāmaḥ
translated: Having approached, we will make offerings to him.

original: atha tāni daśadevaputrasahasrāṇi deveṣu trāyastriṃśatsvantarhitāni jalavāhanasya śriṣṭhino gṛhe tasthuḥ /
analyzed: atha tāni daśa devaputra sahasrāṇi deveṣu trāyastriṃśatsu antarhitāni jalavāhanasya śriṣṭhinaḥ gṛhe tasthuḥ
translated: Then those ten thousand deva sons disappeared among the Thirty-Three Gods and stood in the house of the merchant Jalavāhana.

original: tena khalu punaḥ samayena ca jalavāhanaḥ śreṣṭyupaśayane śayitaḥ /
analyzed: tena khalu punar samayena ca jalavāhanaḥ śreṣṭi upaśayane śayitaḥ
translated: At that time, the merchant Jalavāhana was lying on his bed.

analyzed: yathā ca saḥ karuṇa vacaḥ hi avocata samīkṣya tām sva tanāya bhakṣaṇa udyatām
translated: And as he spoke those compassionate words, seeing her ready to eat her own flesh,

original: kṣudhānvitāṃ vyaśanaśataiḥ samanvitāṃ sudurbalā matiriha saṃśayā tu me // / //
analyzed: kṣudhā anvitām vyaśana śataiḥ samanvitām su durbalā matiḥ iha saṃśayā tu me
translated: afflicted with hunger and hundreds of calamities, my mind is greatly doubtful here.

original: atha tau rājakumārau paramaśokābhibhūtau vāṣpapariplutākṣau tamenaṃ panthānaṃ pratinivṛtya gacchantau vyāghrīsamīpamevābhijagmatuḥ /
analyzed: atha tau rāja kumārau parama śoka abhibhūtau vāṣpa paripluta akṣau tam enam panthānam pratinivṛtya gacchantau vyāghrī samīpam eva abhijagmatuḥ
translated: Then the two princes, overwhelmed with great sorrow, their eyes filled with tears, turned back from that path and went to the vicinity of the tigress.

original: taṃ dadṛśtuḥ śataṃ vaṃśalatāsamāyuktaṃ prāvaraṇaṃ kṛṣṇavikṛṣṇāni Bagchi
analyzed: tam dadṛśtuḥ śatam vaṃśa latā samāyuktam prāvaraṇam kṛṣṇa vikṛṣṇāni
translated: They saw the hundred bamboo shoots that were her covering, her black and bluish bones,

analyzed: ca asthīni rudhira kardamāni
translated: and the muddy blood.

original: nānādigvidikṣu keśānvistīrṇāndṛṣṭvā ca samūrcchannau bhūmau nipetatuḥ /
analyzed: nānā diś vidikṣu keśān vistīrṇān dṛṣṭvā ca sa mūrcchannau bhūmau nipetatuḥ
translated: Seeing the scattered hair in the various directions, they fainted and fell to the ground.

analyzed: sacirāt saṃjñām upalabhya utthāya ucceya bāhū ārta svaram mumucatuḥ
translated: After a long time, they regained consciousness, rose up, raised their arms, and let out a cry of distress.

original: aho priyabhrātṛka pārthivāyaṃ tathā jananī sutavatsalā yā
analyzed: aho priya bhrātṛka pārthiva ayam tathā jananī suta vatsalā yā
translated: Oh, how dear to his brother is this king! And how loving is the mother to her son!

original: pṛcchiṣyate sā jananī tṛtīyaḥ kva vā yuvābhyāṃ kamalāyatekṣṇaḥ // / //
analyzed: pṛcchiṣyate sā jananī tṛtīyaḥ kva vā yuvābhyām kamala āyata īkṣṇaḥ
translated: That mother, who will ask Where are the two young ones with eyes like lotus petals?

original: aho hi asmākamihaiva śobhitaṃ nanū pradeśe maraṇaṃ na jīvitam /
analyzed: aho hi asmākam iha eva śobhitam nanu pradeśe maraṇam na jīvitam
translated: Oh, how splendid it is for us to die here in this very place, not to live!

analyzed: katham mahāsattva vivarjitāḥ vayam dāsyāmahe darśanam ambatātayoḥ
translated: How can we, deprived of the Great Being, give sight to our mother and father?

original: atha tau rājakumārau bahuvividhakaruṇaṃ vilāpya pracakramatuḥ /
analyzed: atha tau rāja kumārau bahu vividha karuṇam vilāpya pracakramatuḥ
translated: Then the two princes, having lamented in various ways, set out.

original: tatra kumārasyopasthāyakā diśi vidiśi pradhāvantaḥ kumārānveṣaṇāḥ parasparaṃ dṛṣṭvā ca papracchuḥ kva kumāraḥ kva kumāra iti /
analyzed: tatra kumārasya upasthāyakāḥ diśi vidiśi pradhāvantaḥ kumāra anveṣaṇāḥ parasparam dṛṣṭvā ca papracchuḥ kva kumāraḥ kva kumāraḥ iti
translated: There, the attendants of the prince, running in all directions in search of the prince, seeing each other, asked, Where is the prince? Where is the prince?

original: tasmiṃśca samaye devī śayanatalagatā priyaviprayogasūcakaṃ svapnaṃ dadarśa /
analyzed: tasmin ca samaye devī śayana tala gatā priya viprayoga sūcakam svapnam dadarśa
translated: And at that time, the queen, lying on her bed, saw a dream foreboding separation from her beloved.

original: tadyathā stanau chidyamānau dantotpātanaṃ ca kriyamāṇaṃ trayaḥ kapotaśāvakāḥ pratilambhamānāste bhītā eva śyenenācchidyamānāḥ /
analyzed: tat yathā stanau chidyamānau danta utpātanam ca kriyamāṇam trayaḥ kapota śāvakāḥ pratilambhamānāḥ te bhītāḥ eva śyenena ācchidyamānāḥ
translated: Namely, she saw her breasts being cut off, her teeth being pulled out, and three young pigeons being taken, frightened, and carried off by a hawk.

original: atha devī bhūmikāmpādutrastahṛdayā sahasā prativibudhya cintāparā babhūva //
analyzed: atha devī bhūmi kāmpādu trasta hṛdayā sahasā prativibudhya cintā parā babhūva
translated: Then the queen, her heart trembling, suddenly awoke and became absorbed in thought.

original: kimeṣā bhūtadhātrī jalanidhivasanā kampati bhṛśaṃ sūryaḥ śūlī na raśmirmama ca kica bhūbhajaṃ vayati vā /
analyzed: kim eṣā bhūta dhātrī jalanidhi vasanā kampati bhṛśam sūryaḥ śūlī na raśmiḥ mama ca kica bhū bhajam vayati vā
translated: Why does this earth, clothed in the ocean, tremble so violently? Does the sun, with its rays, afflict me or my son?

original: duḥkhaṃ kurvati me gātraṃ calati ca nayanaṃ svastanaṃ chidyatī ca /
analyzed: duḥkham kurvati me gātram calati ca nayanam sva stanam chidyatī ca
translated: My body is pained, my eyes move, and my breast is torn.

original: svasti me syātsutānāṃ vanavivaramidaṃ krīḍanārthaṃ gatānām // / //
analyzed: svasti me syāt sutānām vana vivaram idam krīḍana artham gatānām
translated: May it be well with me and my sons who have gone to this forest grove to play.

original: athaivaṃ cintayantyāśceṭī ca saṃtrastahṛdayā praviśya devyā nivedayāmāsa /
analyzed: athā evam cintayantyāḥ ceṭī ca saṃtrasta hṛdayā praviśya devyāḥ nivedayāmāsa
translated: Then, while she was thinking thus, a maid servant, her heart trembling, entered and reported to the queen:

analyzed: devi kumāra paricārakāḥ kumāram anveṣante naṣṭaḥ śrūyate
translated: Your Highness, the attendants of the princes are searching for the prince. It is heard that he is lost.

original: tatra putrahataśravaṇācca devī saṃkampitāhṛdayā vāṣpākulanayanavadanā Bagchi
analyzed: tatra putra hata śravaṇāt ca devī saṃkampita a hṛdayā vāṣpa ākula nayana vadanā
translated: There, hearing of the death of her son, the queen's heart trembled. Her eyes and face were filled with tears. She

analyzed: rājānam abhigamya uvāca
translated: approached the king and said:

analyzed: deva naṣṭaḥ me priya sutaḥ śrūyate
translated: Your Highness, my beloved son is lost. It is heard that he is dead.

analyzed: rājā api saṃkampita hṛdayaḥ parama saṃtrāsam āpede
translated: The king also, his heart trembling, fell into a great panic.

analyzed: hā kaṣṭam viyuktaḥ smi priya sutena
translated: Alas, I am separated from my beloved son.

analyzed: atha rājā devīm āśvāsayāmāsa
translated: Then the king comforted the queen:🔽Your Highness, do not grieve. Our son is not dead.

analyzed: mā bhīḥ devi putra artham vayam kumāra anveṣaṇa upalabhantaḥ
translated: Do not fear, O Queen, for your sons. We are engaged in searching for the princes.

original: tatra pravṛtte kumārānveṣaṇābhidrute janakāya athācirādeva rājā dadarśa dūrata evāgacchantau rājakumārau /
analyzed: tatra pravṛtte kumāra anveṣaṇa abhidrute jana kāya atha acirāt eva rājā dadarśa dūratas eva āgacchantau rāja kumārau
translated: There, when the people were engaged in searching for the princes, the king soon saw the two princes coming from afar.

analyzed: dṛṣṭvā rājā abravīt
translated: Seeing them, the king said,

analyzed: etau ālabhantau kumārau na tu sarve
translated: Only these two princes are found, not all of them.

analyzed: hā kaṣṭam suta viyogaḥ nāma
translated: Alas, the separation from sons is indeed painful.

original: na bhavati nirupalambhe na prītirevaṃ narāṇāṃ bhavati sutaviyogādyādṛśaṃ daurmanasyam /
analyzed: na bhavati nirupalambhe na prītiḥ evam narāṇām bhavati suta viyogāt yādṛśam daurmanasyam
translated: When there is no perception, there is no such joy for men as the sorrow caused by separation from sons.

original: nanu varasukhinaste yena puṃsābhiyogā maraṇamupagatā vā ye na jīvanti putrāḥ // / //
analyzed: nanu vara sukhinaḥ te yena puṃsā abhiyogāḥ maraṇam upagatāḥ vā ye na jīvanti putrāḥ
translated: Are not those men who have died or who do not live due to the efforts of their sons very happy?

original: atha devī paramaśokābhibhūtā marmahanteva kalabhī ārtasvaramuvāca //
analyzed: atha devī parama śoka abhibhūtā marma hantā iva kalabhī ārta svaram uvāca
translated: Then the queen, overcome by great sorrow, like a cow struck in a vital part, spoke in a voice of distress:

original: yadi tanayāstrayasya bhṛtyavargā vanavare kusumākule praviṣṭāḥ /
analyzed: yadi tanayāḥ trayasya bhṛtya vargāḥ vana vare kusuma ākule praviṣṭāḥ
translated: If the three sons and the groups of servants have entered the excellent forest full of flowers,

original: kva sa hṛdayasamo samastṛtīyaḥ sutamanayāpadavaiti kanīyasametat // / //
analyzed: kva sa hṛdaya samaḥ samaḥ tṛtīyaḥ sutam anayā āpad avaiti kanīyasam etat
translated: where is that one who is like my heart, the youngest son, together with the third? He is not seen.

original: tayorāgatayo rājā putrāvetatparyapṛcchatotsukaḥ kumārau paripṛcchati sma /
analyzed: tayoḥ āgatayoḥ rājā putrau etat paryapṛcchata utsukaḥ kumārau paripṛcchati sma
translated: When they arrived, the king, eager, asked the two princes about this. He inquired about the princes:

analyzed: kva dārakaḥ kanīyasaḥ iti
translated: Where is the youngest child?

original: tataḥ śokārtāvaśrudrutanayanau pariśuṣkatālvoṣṭhadaśanavadanau na kiñcidūcatuḥ // devyuvāca //
analyzed: tatas śoka ārtau aśru druta nayanau pariśuṣka tālu oṣṭha daśana vadanau na kiñcid ūcatuḥ devī uvāca
translated: Then, overwhelmed with grief, their eyes filled with tears, their tongues, lips, and mouths dry, they said nothing. The queen said:

original: kathayatāṃ laghu vimuhyati smṛtiśca paramabhṛśaṃ paripīḍyate ca dehaḥ /
analyzed: kathayatām laghu vimuhyati smṛtiḥ ca parama bhṛśam paripīḍyate ca dehaḥ
translated: Speak quickly, my memory is confused and my body is greatly afflicted.

original: kva sa mama putrastṛtīya hṛdayaṃ idaṃ sphuṭitaṃ tu saṃmūrcchati vā // / //
analyzed: kva sa mama putraḥ tṛtīya hṛdayam idam sphuṭitam tu saṃmūrcchati vā
translated: Where is my son, my third heart? It bursts and is about to faint.

original: atha tau kumārau vistareṇa taṃ vṛttāntaṃ nivedayāmāsa /
analyzed: atha tau kumārau vistareṇa tam vṛttāntam nivedayāmāsa
translated: Then the two princes related the whole story in detail.

analyzed: saha śravaṇena rājā devī parijanāḥ ca moham upagatāḥ
translated: As soon as the king, the queen, and the attendants heard it, they fell into a faint.

analyzed: moha pratyāgatāḥ ca karuṇā ārta svaram rodamānāḥ tam deśam abhijagmuḥ
translated: Having regained consciousness, they wept with cries of sorrow and went to that place.

original: atha rājā devī ca taṇyasthīnyapagatarudhiramāṃsāni vāyunā diśo vidiśaśca keśavikīrṇā dṛṣṭvā Bagchi
analyzed: atha rājā devī ca taṇi asthīni apagata rudhira māṃsāni vāyunā diśaḥ vidiśaḥ ca keśa vikīrṇāḥ dṛṣṭvā bagchi
translated: Then the king and the queen, seeing the bones without blood and flesh, scattered in all directions and intermediate directions by the wind, with hair disheveled,

analyzed: ca āhataḥ iva drumaḥ bhūmau nipatitau
translated: fell to the ground like a tree struck down.

original: tataḥ purohitaḥ suciraṃ tāmavasthāṃ dṛṣṭvā salilamalayacandanapaṅkai rājño devyāśca śarīraṃ prahlādayāmāsa /
analyzed: tatas purohitaḥ su ciram tām avasthām dṛṣṭvā salila malaya candana paṅkaiḥ rājñaḥ devyāḥ ca śarīram prahlādayāmāsa
translated: Then the priest, seeing that state for a long time, refreshed the body of the king and the queen with water, sandalwood, and aloe paste.

analyzed: atha su cirāt saṃjñām upalabhya rājā utthāya karuṇa karuṇam vilalāpa
translated: After a long time, regaining consciousness, the king rose and lamented piteously:

original: hā kaṣṭaṃ putra kva manorasa darśanīya mṛtyorvaśaṃ śīghramupagatāsi /
analyzed: hā kaṣṭam putra kva manorasa darśanīya mṛtyoḥ vaśam śīghram upagatā asi
translated: Alas, my son, where have you gone, so handsome and delightful? You have quickly come under the power of death.

original: mṛtyoḥ praśmameva hi cāgato vinā te paraṃ mama bhaviṣyati duḥkhamanyat // / //
analyzed: mṛtyoḥ praśmam eva hi ca āgataḥ vinā te param mama bhaviṣyati duḥkham anyat
translated: For without you, my son, there will be only grief for me, nothing else.

original: devī ca mohātyāgatā prakīrṇakeśī bāhubhyāmurastāḍayantī sthānyāṃ pluta iva matsyā dharaṇyāstale parivartamānā mahiṣīva naṣṭavatsā kalabhīva 🔽naṣṭaśāvakā karuṇakaruṇaṃ roditi //🔽hā kānta priyasuta kena vrajase bhagno 'yaṃ padmo dharaṇītale hi vikīrṇaḥ /
analyzed: devī ca moha atyāgatā prakīrṇa keśī bāhubhyām uraḥ tāḍayantī sthānyām plutaḥ iva matsyāḥ dharaṇyāḥ tale parivartamānā mahiṣī iva naṣṭa vatsā kalabhī iva  naṣṭa śāvakā karuṇa karuṇam roditi  hā kānta priya suta kena vrajase bhagnaḥ yam padmaḥ dharaṇī tale hi vikīrṇaḥ
translated: And the queen, overcome by delusion, with disheveled hair, beating her breasts with her arms, rolling on the ground like a fish out of water, like a cow that has lost her calf, like a she-buffalo🔽weeping pitifully, Alas, my beloved son, who has taken you away? This lotus is broken and scattered on the ground.

original: śatruṇā mama bhuvi kena nāśaṃ gato 'dya putro me nayanamanoharacandraḥ
analyzed: śatruṇā mama bhuvi kena nāśam gataḥ dya putraḥ me nayana manohara candraḥ
translated: By what enemy has my son, the moon that delights the eyes and mind, been destroyed on the ground today?

original: hā kiṃ śarīramiha adya na yāti bhagnaṃ paśyāmi haṃ sutavaraṃ nihataṃ pṛthivyām // / //
analyzed: hā kim śarīram iha adya na yāti bhagnam paśyāmi ham suta varam nihatam pṛthivyām
translated: Alas, why does my body not break into a thousand pieces today? I see my excellent son slain on the ground.

original: saṃvyaktaṃ hṛdayamayo mamaitaṃ dhigvyasanaṃ avekṣya no cedbhedayate /
analyzed: saṃvyaktam hṛdayam ayaḥ mama etam dhik vyasanam avekṣya no ced bhedayate
translated: It is clear that my heart is made of stone, for it does not break into a thousand pieces on seeing this misfortune.

analyzed: hā ca etat pāpakam svapna phalam yat chinnau imau adya kenacid asinā
translated: Alas, this is the evil dream result, that these two breasts have been cut off by someone with a sword today.

original: svapnāntare dvau stanau daṃṣṭrotpāṭya me priyasuto nāśaṃ gataḥ śīghramataḥ // / //
analyzed: svapna antare dvau stanau daṃṣṭrā utpāṭya me priya sutaḥ nāśam gataḥ śīghram atas
translated: In a dream, my beloved son, having uprooted my two breasts with his tusks, quickly disappeared.

original: sa śyenenāpahṛto yathaiva iha me labdhaiḥ kapotaistribhiḥ /
analyzed: sa śyenena apahṛtaḥ yathā eva iha me labdhaiḥ kapotaiḥ tribhiḥ
translated: Just as he was carried off by a hawk here, I obtained three pigeons.

original: so me 'dya tribhirātmajaiḥ parivṛta eko hato mṛtyunā // / //
analyzed: saḥ me tribhiḥ ātmajaiḥ parivṛtaḥ ekaḥ hataḥ mṛtyunā
translated: Now, surrounded by my three sons, one has been killed by death.

analyzed: bagchi
translated: Bagchi

original: atha rājā devī ca bahuvidhaṃ karuṇakaruṇaṃ paridevatastayoḥ sarvabharaṇānyavamucya
analyzed: atha rājā devī ca bahuvidham karuṇa karuṇam paridevataḥ tayoḥ sarva bharaṇāni avamucya
translated: Then the king and queen, having lamented in many ways, removed all their ornaments

original: mahatā janakāyena sārdhaṃ putrasya śarīrapūjāṃ kṛtvā tasminpṛthivīpradeśe suvarṇamayacaityeṣu
analyzed: mahatā jana kāyena sārdham putrasya śarīra pūjām kṛtvā tasmin pṛthivī pradeśe suvarṇa maya caityeṣu
translated: and, together with a great crowd of people, performed the body worship of their son. They placed those bodies in golden stupas

analyzed: nyastāni tāni śarīrāṇi
translated: in that place on the earth.

original: syātte khalu punarānandānyaḥ sa tena kālena tena samayena mahāsattvo nāma rājakumāro 'bhūt /
analyzed: syāt te khalu punar ānandān yaḥ sa tena kālena tena samayena mahāsattvaḥ nāma rāja kumāraḥ bhūt
translated: Now, Ānanda, did you think that at that time, on that occasion, the prince named Mahāsattva was someone else?

analyzed: na evam draṣṭavyam
translated: You should not see it like that.

analyzed: tat kasya hetoḥ
translated: Why is that?

original: ahaṃ sa tena kālena tena samayena mahāsattvo nāma rājakumāro 'bhūt /
analyzed: aham sa tena kālena tena samayena mahāsattvaḥ nāma rāja kumāraḥ bhūt
translated: I was the prince named Mahāsattva at that time, on that occasion.

original: tadāpi mayānanda rājadveṣamohāparimuktena narakādibhyaśca duḥkhebhyaḥ kṛpayā jagadanugṛhītam /
analyzed: tadā api mayā ānanda rāja dveṣa moha a parimuktena naraka ādibhyaḥ ca duḥkhebhyaḥ kṛpayā jagat anugṛhītam
translated: Even then, Ananda, by me who was not free from hatred, delusion, and anger towards the king, the world was favored with compassion, and from the sufferings beginning with hell.

analyzed: kim khalu punar idānīm sarvadoṣāpagatena samyaksaṃbuddhena iti
translated: How much more so now, when I am a perfectly enlightened one, free from all faults?

original: evaṃ hyekaikasya sattvasyārthe kalpaṃ samudeyaṃ narakeṣu jātiṃ saṃsārādvimocayeyam /
analyzed: evam hi ekaikasya sattvasya arthe kalpam samudeyam narakeṣu jātim saṃsārāt vimocayeyam
translated: For thus, for the sake of each being, I would arise in hell for an eon and liberate them from samsara.

analyzed: khalu sattva sāraiḥ ca jagat parigṛhītam duṣkaram anekavidha vicitram iti
translated: Indeed, the world is favored by the best of beings with difficult and various practices.

analyzed: atha bhagavān tasyām velāyām imāḥ gāthāḥ abhāṣata
translated: Then the Blessed One spoke these verses on that occasion:

original: bahūni kalpāni mayātmā tyaktaḥ paryeṣayetā imamagrabodhim /
analyzed: bahūni kalpāni mayā ātmā tyaktaḥ paryeṣayeta imam agra bodhim
translated: For many eons, I abandoned my self, seeking this supreme enlightenment.

original: yathāsi rājā yatha rājaputram tathaiva tyaktā maya ātmabhāvāḥ // / //
analyzed: yathā asi rājā rāja putram tathā eva tyaktāḥ maya ātmabhāvāḥ
translated: Just as I was a king, or a prince, so I abandoned my bodies.

original: anusmarami purimāsu jātiṣu mahāratho nāma babhūva rājā /🔽tasyāpi putrau mahātyāgavanto nāmnā mahāsattva varo babhūva // / //
analyzed: anusmarami purimāsu jātiṣu mahārathaḥ nāma babhūva rājā  tasya api putrau mahātyāgavantaḥ nāmnā mahāsattva varaḥ babhūva
translated: I remember in past lives, there was a king named Maharatha.🔽He had two sons, greatly generous, named Mahasattva and Vara.

original: dvau tasya āsīdatha bhrātarau ca nāmnā mahādeva mahāpraṇādaḥ /
analyzed: dvau tasya āsīt atha bhrātarau ca nāmnā mahādeva mahāpraṇādaḥ
translated: He had two brothers named Mahadeva and Mahapranada.

original: vanakhaṇḍa gatvā va samānagotraistairdṛṣṭa vyāghrī kṣudhayābhibhūtā // / //
analyzed: vanakhaṇḍa gatvā samāna gotraiḥ taiḥ dṛṣṭa vyāghrī kṣudhayā abhibhūtā
translated: Having gone to the forest grove, they saw the tigress, overcome by hunger, with her own young ones.

original: tasyāgrasattvasya kṛpābhijātā yannūna haṃ ātma tyajeya māṃsam /🔽Bagchi
analyzed: tasya agra sattvasya kṛpā abhijātā yat nūna haṃ tyajeya māṃsam  bagchi
translated: The compassionate one, the foremost being, thought, I will surely give up my own flesh.

original: eṣā hi vyāghrī kṣudhatarṣapīḍitā khādīya etāni svakātmajāni // / //
analyzed: eṣā hi vyāghrī kṣudha tarṣa pīḍitā khādīya etāni svaka ātmajāni
translated: This tigress, afflicted by hunger and thirst, will eat her own young ones.

analyzed: patitaḥ ca āsīt tadā sa mahā ratha sutaḥ mahā sattvaḥ
